utterances: It was my second week on the job, and there was a funeral for a U.S.
Marine Corps lieutenant colonel, and I had gone out and kind of set up, as I was told, you know, there's a rope line and you have to keep the media back, and so I set it up.
I went to pick up the press, Dana Milbank included, and I got back out there and it had been moved pretty far away.
By whom?
The deputy director of the cemetery.
And on whose instructions?
On whose orders?
Him.
Just his own?
Yes.
And was this a reflection of any policy that you were aware of?
That is - and that was my issue, is that there was no policy.
There was no written policy.
There was no regulation.
There was no standard.
And that was my problem, ultimately, is that there was nothing in black and white to refer to.
There was nothing that you could point definitively to and say, this is the policy.
This is the regulation.
And so, as a result, things would constantly change, and that was my issue.
That it was arbitrary, in a sense.
Yeah.
And bottom line, the cemetery bureaucrats took control away from the families.
I think, ultimately, it is up the families, whether or not media coverage should be allowed, and the family should be the one to determine what media coverage means to them.
Dana Milbank, as Gina Gray just said, you were there that day.
Why were you there?
And tell us about the experience from your point of view?
Well, I had gone, as I do occasionally, to write a column about a funeral.
I had last done it a few years earlier, and it was quite a moving ceremony.
I returned to do what I thought would be the same thing, then realized suddenly that we could neither hear nor see what was going on.
So, I actually wrote about that experience of not quite seeing or hearing the funeral.
And I had not realized that this set off this internal debate that ultimately led onto Gina's firing.
And Gina, are you convinced that your dismissal was retaliatory?
Absolutely.
Yeah, I am.
What is it, more than anything, that points that out to you?
I think just from that moment - from the day that the Lieutenant Colonel Hall funeral occurred, and I had put my foot down and started questioning, you know, where are these regulations?
And then when I couldn't find them, I began questioning that further, and I think from that point on, it was very hostile and just kind of contentious.

Arlington has a very special place in country's memory.

Gretchen, thanks very much for the call.
I appreciate it.

My brother was killed by a roadside bomb in Iraq and buried at Arlington National Cemetery, actually, last year, and my family did decide to permit media coverage on - at the funeral.
And again, we're so sorry for your loss, but what happened when - what went into the thinking?
Did people talk about it?
We actually had an internal family discussion about what we wanted to do with media coverage.
I actually work in media relations, and have for over a decade, and so, I spoke with my parents about what they wanted.
And our decision, as a family, was that we wanted to find a place of middle ground, which was we did not want coverage that was exploitative.
We wanted to seek coverage that would honor my brother and the sacrifice that he had made, and that would honor his life.
And so, for us that meant that the first week after my brother was killed, before we even went to Arlington for the funeral, we did not do any on-camera interviews.
We did do an interview with our local newspaper.

And we did feel that, in the case of Arlington National Cemetery, that the media - we knew they would be back a ways, but that the pictures and video that they would get would also help our whole community grieve, because my brother grew up in this community.
And in the event, did it?

I think that it did help our community, because 40,000 people could not go from a small town to watch their local hero be buried at Arlington National Cemetery, and yet, there were hundreds of people who were deeply moved by my brother's death.
And I think it was a way for people to be able to experience that and to also, you know, be part of that experience.
